title: Thunderbird has problems notifying of unread eMail when folders are nested.
content:
When one has nested folders in a Thunderbird account the notification of unread mail is not being propagated up to ALL the folders in the chain to the head of the nest.

My Thunderbird often does not mark the account when new email has arrived.

When It does mark the account, all the folders underneath are UNmarked so one has to go on a fishing trip opening each containing folder until the unread email is highlighted.

eg:

An Account is sometimes marked as having unread email folder1 (no marking) subFolder1 (no marking) subfolder2 (no marking) subSubFolder (sometines marked) email is marked as unread folder2 subFolder1 subFolder2 subSubFolder3

folder3

Any suggestions?? Thank you. Ross

title: TB v115.5.1
content:
Folks, I moved to v115.5.1 (from 102.5.1) on Dec. 2. Below, are issues I have encountered.

1. Messages being downloaded when they should not. 

On Dec. 11,  I found that 414 messages had been downloaded to an account that is set to download nothing.  The following server settings are NOT checked:  Check for new messages at startup, Check for new messages every n minutes, and Automatically download new messages.  The messages were from as far back as Oct. 11, 2023.  In another account, messages from 2016, 2017, etc. were downloaded.  In the version 102 this never happened.

Why this happened: When “Get Messages” is selected, messages in ALL accounts are attempted to be downloaded. This is a MAJOR deviation from version 102. In version 102, only the selected account would be processed. - NOT all accounts!!! For me, this makes the Get Messages function unusable and a noteworthy problem.

2. Does not return to previously selected message. 

When moving back to a previously selected account folder and message, the message is not selected.  It lands on the account but not the message.  This is a very handy placeholder when moving between folders.

3. Message is not displayed . When selecting a folder for the first time in the session the contents for the first message are not displayed. Most often it is the message that needs to be seen. Again, a deviation from v.102.

Regards, Roger
creator: AvidResearcher

title: Unable To Login - Thunderbird Failed To Find the Settings For Your Email Account
content:
Upon initial setup, Thunderbird says the ISP is recognized and auto-populates all the settings. Well of course these settings don't work and I'm unable to log in and receive some sort of message saying it didn't work. If I login using a browser via cellphone, I'm provided with the list of settings to use with email clients which is as follows:

Domain: @hot.rr.com SSL: On for SMTP and IMAP Protocol: IMAP Incoming Server: mail.twc.com Incoming Server Port: 993 Outgoing Server: mail.twc.com Outgoing Server Port: 587 Requires Authentication: Yes, or checked

Using these settings in manual configuration results in receiving the "Thunderbird Failed To Find the Settings For Your Email Account" message. The only difference between the settings that were auto-populated and the settings provided by logging in via web browser on a cellphone are the incoming/outgoing servers. Auto-population had them as mobile.charter.net, and they're listed as mail.twc.com by the email provider to use with email clients.

I'm trying to solve this problem for someone else and they happen to have the same email domain as me so I can fiddle with it without having to be at their computer with their passwords, etc. Presumably if I'm able to find the solution it will work for both of us. I don't normally use Thunderbird or any other email client, I just use web based email but they prefer to use a client. However, I'm doubtful that it will work considering the fact that settings provided by the email provider don't work.

Any input is appreciated.
creator: Rubbishization

title: Search finds emails that then are unavailable to open
content:
I have two emails dated 11/22/2021 from support@emarkys.com. If I do a global search for them using either “markys” or “emarkys” I get a drop-down window, image attached, that shows an option for support@emarkys.com. If I click on that I get a search tab that opens showing the two emails. If I click on either of them, I just get a blank screen in a new tab. If I click “Show results as list” I get a blank screen in a new tab.

The emails are located in a local folder “__Purchases” If I search for them using a quick search within the folder they are found just fine and open fine.

I have tried global searches for other emails in that folder and some work fine, but others do not, which is to say they fail like the markys search.

I did a right click on the Purchase folder and selected Repair. The folder only has 147 emails so it completed very quickly. But when it is done the folder appears to have no emails in it. If I click to another local folder and then click back to __Purchases all the emails are there.

After the Repair the search problems persist. I rebooted the PC and the problem persisted.

I tried repairing other local folders that also have name beginning with a double underscore and they repair fine and search fine.

NOW this is really odd. I went to my SurfaceGo to try the same search. Periodically I copy C:\Users\...\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\y6jsbo3s.default to transfer my main PC’s TBird install on that machine. I did the same search on that machine and it worked ok. No problems. Then just for the heck of it I did a repair on the Purchases folder. Unlike the other machine, it appeared to repair fine and all the emails were there without me having to click on another folder. However, when I did the search for Markys I now had the same problem as on the other machine. It no longer worked.

Using TB 115.5.2 in Win10Pro 22H2 OS Build 19045.3693
creator: eberger5

title: thinkpad updates and windows 11 pro crashes
content:
Hi, new here and need help with a potential Thunderbird-related issue:

In the last month or two, my machine (a Thinkpad laptop, e15) has crashed three times without warning, not even a BSOD. On rebooting and logging into Windows and running FireFox, the first thing that happens is the launch of a Thunderbird update. This has occurred on all three occasions.

Although I usually have Thunderbird open when using the laptop, I open/close it at least three or four times a day, so this is not a case of an app allowed to remain open for more than a few hours.

Today, I disabled automatic updates in the Thunderbird settings, though I find it questionable whether Thunderbird has anything to do with this.

Has anyone else experienced this "coincidence"?
